Description.val:
The Evolved SEASPARROW Missile (ESSM) Program is an international cooperative effort among twelve NATO SEASPARROW nations (Australia, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Germany, Greece, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Turkey, and the U.S.) established to design, develop, test, produce and provide in-service support to a new and improved version of the SPARROW missile (RIM-7P) with the kinematic performance to defeat current and projected threats that possess low altitude, high velocity ,and maneuvering characteristics beyond the engagement capabilities of the RIM-7P. ESSM consists of Blk 1 and Blk 2 missiles. 

ESSM Blk 2 provides crucial defense battlespace and fire power against the fast, low altitude, highly maneuverable Anti-Ship Cruise Missile (ASCM) threat. ESSM Blk 2 upgrade replaces the largely obsolete guidance section with a dual mode Active/Semi-Active X-Band seeker capable of defeating future threat capabilities within the existing envelope, including: smaller signatures, increased raid sizes, and adverse environments including countermeasures. Threat types include: advanced ASCMs, Anti-Ship Ballistic Missiles, surface and asymmetrical.  Two ESSM Blk 2 Controlled Test Vehicle flight tests were successfully conducted in June 2017 onboard the Self Defense Test Ship at the Point Mugu Sea Range. Two Guided Test Vehicle (GTV) flight tests were completed, GTV-1 was completed in June 2018 and GTV-2 was completed in October 2018. GTV-3 round was repurposed for OT Risk Reduction shot prior to Operational Testing (OT). GTV-3 objectives will be tested in Developmental Testing (DT).  The ESSM Blk 2 Milestone C decision was successfully completed in Q2 FY 2019, supporting Initial Operational Capability for AEGIS platforms scheduled for 2020 and SSDS platforms in 2023. ESSM Blk 2 Low Rate Initial Production deliveries are expected to begin in 2020 with Full Rate Production rounds delivering to the Fleet in 2023.

Production Support for ESSM Blk 2 reflects the U.S. Share under the cooperative Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with Consortium Partners and directly results in the number of missiles each FY. The US is responsible for approximately 45% of the missile production support under this approved MOU.  This amount is required for the US to meet its MOU commitment with Consortium Partners.  ESSM is currently on a rigid schedule with FY 2018 Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP) deliveries beginning in August 2020 to support AEGIS Initial Operational Capability (IOC) in September 2020.

Justification.val:
Increase in overall FY 2021 funding from FY 2020 is due to an increase in the procurement of 50 LRIP rounds in FY 2020 to 120 FRP rounds in FY 2021.
LRIP 1-3 unit cost are negotiated contract prices.

FY 2021 funding increase in MK25 Mod 1 Canisters due to an increase in the procurement quantity from 13 in FY 2020 to 24 in FY 2021 to accommodate missile procurement (4 missiles per canister and 1 missile per MK852 MOD 0)

FY 2021 funding increase in MK852 Mod 0 Shipping containers due to an increase in the procurement quantity from 0 in FY 2020 to 24 in FY 2021 to accommodate missile procurement (4 missiles per canister and 1 missile per MK852 MOD 0)

Increase in FY 2021 Obsolescence funding ($1.2M) will be going towards designing out obsolete parts associated with the following: 1.) Side-Looking-Subsystem (SLS) Signal Processor (SP) Circuit Card Assembly (CCA), 2.)Form-Fit-Function (F3R) re-spins of the Dual Band Transceiver (DBT) Frequency Reference Unit (FRU), and 3.) F3R re-spins of the FRU Oscillator, Frequency Generator, and Radio Frequency (RF).

Common Munitions Built In Test (BIT) and Reprogramming Equipment (CMBRE) requirement (including procurement, adaptors, spares, power supply, and cables) begins in FY 2021. This was approved by OPNAV Sponsor and is used to reprogram ESSM Blk 2 AURs in deployed locations.  CMBRE will allow the USN to perform reprogramming of the ESSM Blk 2 missile in the field. Specifically at forward deployed locations, either shore based or on the ships when deployed. Previously, reprogramming required the return of the missiles to the Seal Beach, CA Intermediate Level Maintenance Facility (ILMF). **CMBRE procurement is part of an already negotiated contract. Unit cost shown in FY 2021 President's Budget Request shows the negotiated price on the current contract ($202K).**

Increase in Test Equipment ($2.7M) is being used to procure a MK698 test set upgrade with ESSM Blk 2 test set spares and an ESSM Blk 2 Inert Operation Missile (IOM)- needed to support recertification and software upgrades at the Seal Beach Intermediate Level Maintenance Facility (ILMF). 

Increase in production support from FY 2020 to FY 2021 reflects the US share of the ESSM Blk 2 Production Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) estimate for FY 2021. The estimated amounts (phasing for the Production MOU) are based on the updated life-cycle cost estimate completed during MS C (March 2019). 
FY21 Production Support details are below:
1.) Producibility/Procurement Support ($9.675M): Government technical oversight on production and redesign engineering, reviews and approval of technical changes to the technical data packages and production drawings, and calibration/certification to test equipment used to support production. Support to keep the missile producible throughout the life of production and support to maintain producibility of the production line. Provide ordnance to the fleet to support the ordnance assessment (OA) program and evaluate the effects of aging energetics to continue safe use of the components through management of their service life. 
2.) Security and Infrastructure Support ($7.020M): Costs required for the shared (across multiple missile families) production facility in Tucson, AZ. 
3.) Configuration Management ($450K): Support for the system performance per the Navy weapon specifications.
4.) Hardware/Maintenance Support ($1.8M): Support for the IOM in the production line.

Name.@footnote: There are four (4) missiles per MK 25 Quadpack Canister.

There is one (1) missile per MK 852 Mod 0. MK 852 Canisters were not required in FY20 because all of the missiles in FY20 are going to AEGIS ships which are MK25 Mod 1s. MK852s are just transport containers that go to Ship Self Defense System (SSDS) ships to be loaded. SSDS ships won't be modified to take delivery of ESSM Blk 2 AURs until FY23 (procurement in FY21 with delivery 18-24 months).
